### Summary Attribution:

-   **Claim:** The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has postponed its vote on the final version of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) for shipping decarbonization by one year.
    -   **Supported by:** "The International Maritime Organization (IMO) just postponed by one year its vote on the final version of the rules to deal with the decarbonisation of shipping, rules referred to as the Net Zero Framework (NZF)."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping calls time on EU climate overreach"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This delay was reportedly influenced by procedural tactics from several nations including the United States, Saudi Arabia, and Russia.
    -   **Supported by:** "The delay was driven by what sources describe as procedural tactics by the United States, Saudi Arabia, Russia and other petrostates, with the motion to delay put forward by Singapore and called to a vote by Saudi Arabia."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping Industry Reaffirms Support for IMO as Global Regulator Following Carbon Pricing Delay"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The delay has drawn disappointment from industry groups seeking regulatory clarity.
    -   **Supported by:** "Following the delay, Kazakos said: “We are disappointed that member states have not been able to agree a way forward at this meeting. Industry needs clarity to be able to make the investments needed to decarbonise the maritime sector, in line with the goals set out in the IMO GHG strategy."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping Industry Reaffirms Support for IMO as Global Regulator Following Carbon Pricing Delay"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Critics suggest the proposed framework, which would have introduced a global carbon pricing system, was perceived by some as a "tax on shipping".
    -   **Supported by:** "There are no technologies nor zero carbon fuels deployable at scale quickly enough to achieve shipping decarbonisation so de facto this proposed NZF is in fact just a tax on shipping."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping calls time on EU climate overreach"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This perception was due to the current lack of scalable zero-carbon fuels and technologies.
    -   **Supported by:** "There are no technologies nor zero carbon fuels deployable at scale quickly enough to achieve shipping decarbonisation so de facto this proposed NZF is in fact just a tax on shipping."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping calls time on EU climate overreach"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The maritime industry, through a Tripartite Forum of shipbuilders, shipowners, and classification societies, has reaffirmed its support for the IMO as the global regulator.
    -   **Supported by:** "The Tripartite Forum of shipbuilders, shipowners and classification societies convened in Busan, South Korea last week, bringing together more than 70 delegates from 13 countries to reaffirm their support for the International Maritime Organization as the global regulator for international shipping."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping Industry Reaffirms Support for IMO as Global Regulator Following Carbon Pricing Delay"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This underscores the need for enforceable global standards despite the current fragmentation.
    -   **Supported by:** "As an industry we will continue to work with the IMO, which is the best organisation to deliver the global regulations needed for a global industry.”"
    -   **From article:** "Shipping Industry Reaffirms Support for IMO as Global Regulator Following Carbon Pricing Delay"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The delay could push the framework's entry into force beyond the originally planned March 2027.
    -   **Supported by:** "The delay will push the adoption vote to the next session in October 2026, potentially risking the deal not coming into force until 2030, even if adopted in a year’s time. The original entry into force of the framework was planned for March 2027."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping Industry Reaffirms Support for IMO as Global Regulator Following Carbon Pricing Delay"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The FuelEU Maritime regulation, a key part of the EU's "fit for 55" legislative package, is moving forward.
    -   **Supported by:** "As part of the European Commission’s fit for 55 legislative package, the FuelEU maritime regulation (regulation (EU) 2023/1805) promotes the use of renewable, low-carbon fuels and clean energy technologies for ships, essential to support decarbonisation in the sector."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Full application of FuelEU Maritime is set for January 1, 2025.
    -   **Supported by:** "The regulation is fully applied from 1 January 2025 except for articles 8 and 9 on monitoring plans that are applied from August 2024."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Monitoring plans for FuelEU Maritime apply from August 2024.
    -   **Supported by:** "The regulation is fully applied from 1 January 2025 except for articles 8 and 9 on monitoring plans that are applied from August 2024."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This regulation mandates a gradual reduction in the yearly average greenhouse gas intensity of energy used by ships over 5,000 gross tonnage calling at European ports.
    -   **Supported by:** "FuelEU maritime sets maximum limits for the yearly average greenhouse gas (GHG) intensity of the energy used by ships above 5,000 gross tonnage calling at European ports, regardless of their flag."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** It targets an 80% reduction by 2050 compared to 2020 levels.
    -   **Supported by:** "Targets will ensure that the greenhouse gas intensity of fuels used in the sector will gradually decrease over time, starting with a 2% decrease by 2025 and reaching up to an 80% reduction by 2050."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** It also requires passenger and container ships at berth to use onshore power supply or other zero-emission technologies from 2030.
    -   **Supported by:** "To reduce air pollution in ports, passenger and container ships at berth or moored at the quayside must use on-shore power supply (OPS) or alternative zero-emission technologies from 1 January 2030 onwards in ports covered under article 9 of the alternative fuels infrastructure regulation (AFIR)..."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The regulation adopts a goal-based, technology-neutral approach.
    -   **Supported by:** "By taking a goal-based and technology-neutral approach, FuelEU maritime allows for innovation and the development of new sustainable fuels and energy conversion technologies..."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This allows operators flexibility in achieving compliance.
    -   **Supported by:** "...offering operators the freedom to decide which fuels and technologies to use based on ship-specific or operation-specific profiles."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Its application is delayed in Norway and Iceland.
    -   **Supported by:** "FuelEU delayed in Norway and Iceland (dated 18.12.2025): Due to delays in the process of incorporating the FuelEU maritime regulation into the EEA Agreement, the application of the regulation will be delayed in Norway and Iceland."
    -   **From article:** "Decarbonising maritime transport – FuelEU Maritime"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The continuous updates to this living document highlight its ongoing relevance and impact on Maersk's European operations.
    -   **Unsupported.** The source mentions implementing acts related to FuelEU, but the statement about Maersk's operations is an interpretive statement, not a factual claim supported by the provided sources.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A

-   **Claim:** A potential showdown over new port fees between the US and China, initially introduced to address shipbuilding dominance, has been postponed.
    -   **Supported by:** "The United States has postponed higher port charges on Chinese-built vessels, a move initially aimed at challenging Beijing’s dominance in global shipbuilding."
    -   **From article:** "Port fee showdown postponed as US and China return to talks"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This postponement followed high-level talks.
    -   **Supported by:** "China’s stock market climbed to decade highs on Thursday as presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping met for the first time in six years — with one major outcome for shipping being the suspension of new port fees both countries had introduced earlier this month."
    -   **From article:** "Port fee showdown postponed as US and China return to talks"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** These fees, based on vessel characteristics and ownership, had introduced significant uncertainty for the maritime sector.
    -   **Supported by:** "The fees, introduced by both Washington and Beijing, were structured around a vessel’s ownership, operation, flag, and place of build — a design that industry players said blurred traditional definitions and created uncertainty across the maritime sector."
    -   **From article:** "Port fee showdown postponed as US and China return to talks"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Separately, the EU has unexpectedly lifted sanctions on two polar-class heavy-lift vessels.
    -   **Supported by:** "In a surprise move the EU has delisted two polar class heavy lift vessels, Audax and Pugnax."
    -   **From article:** "EU Lifts Sanctions on Heavy-Load Carriers ‘Audax’ and ‘Pugnax’ Involved in Russian Arctic LNG Construction"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** These vessels were previously involved in Russian Arctic LNG construction.
    -   **Supported by:** "The vessels were purpose-built for the construction of Russia’s Yamal LNG project in 2016. They also carried the majority of prefabricated modules for the country’s other flagship LNG project, Arctic LNG 2."
    -   **From article:** "EU Lifts Sanctions on Heavy-Load Carriers ‘Audax’ and ‘Pugnax’ Involved in Russian Arctic LNG Construction"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** The reasons for the delisting are not immediately clear.
    -   **Supported by:** "The EU press office did not immediately respond to a request for comment why the two vessels were delisted last week."
    -   **From article:** "EU Lifts Sanctions on Heavy-Load Carriers ‘Audax’ and ‘Pugnax’ Involved in Russian Arctic LNG Construction"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This development underscores the dynamic nature of geopolitical sanctions and their potential impact on global shipping and energy supply chains.
    -   **Unsupported.** This is an interpretive statement, not a factual claim supported by the provided sources.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A

-   **Claim:** Maersk, through its APM Terminals division, is making a substantial investment of $2 billion as part of a broader $5 billion India infrastructure plan.
    -   **Supported by:** "Meanwhile, APM Terminals Pipavav signed an MoU with the Gujarat Maritime Board for a $2bn expansion of the Pipavav port, one of India’s most efficient private gateways. The investment is part of A.P. Moller – Maersk’s $5bn India infrastructure plan, first unveiled earlier this year..."
    -   **From article:** "India nets $7bn in fresh investment from DP World and Maersk"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This commitment, alongside a $5 billion investment from DP World, aims to significantly expand port and logistics infrastructure across India.
    -   **Supported by:** "India’s ambitions to become a global maritime powerhouse have gained major momentum, with Dubai-based DP World and Danish group APM Terminals announcing fresh investments worth more than $7bn combined to expand port and logistics infrastructure across the country. DP World will invest an additional $5bn to strengthen its integrated supply chain and logistics network in India..."
    -   **From article:** "India nets $7bn in fresh investment from DP World and Maersk"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** These investments focus on strengthening integrated supply chains, improving multimodal connectivity, and promoting "green coastal shipping."
    -   **Supported by:** "The funding will support multimodal connectivity, lower logistics costs, and drive export competitiveness, the company said. Among the key partnerships, DP World’s feeder operator, Unifeeder, signed an MoU with Sagarmala Finance Corporation to promote sustainable coastal shipping..."
    -   **From article:** "India nets $7bn in fresh investment from DP World and Maersk"
    -   **Confidence:** High (This applies to DP World's investment, which is part of "these investments" in the claim).

-   **Claim:** Initiatives include piloting India's first automated low-emission port track system.
    -   **Supported by:** "DP World also inked a deal with Deendayal Port Authority and Nevomo (MagRail) to pilot India’s first automated low-emission port track system."
    -   **From article:** "India nets $7bn in fresh investment from DP World and Maersk"
    -   **Confidence:** High (Note: The source attributes this initiative specifically to DP World).

-   **Claim:** This aligns directly with Maersk's mission to decarbonize global supply chains and enhance its competitive edge through scalable sustainability solutions.
    -   **Unsupported.** This is an interpretive statement about Maersk's mission and competitive edge, not a factual claim supported by the provided sources.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A

-   **Claim:** The Indian engineering conglomerate Larsen & Toubro (L&T), in partnership with Hitachi Energy, has stepped in to deliver high-voltage direct-current (HVDC) converter stations for TenneT’s 2GW offshore wind program in the German and Dutch North Sea.
    -   **Supported by:** "Indian engineering conglomerate Larsen & Toubro (L&T) has replaced Petrofac in the high-voltage direct-current (HVDC) offshore wind programme led by Germany’s transmission system operator TenneT. In partnership with Hitachi Energy, L&T will deliver HVDC converter stations for the project, which aims to accelerate the integration of large-scale renewable energy into the European power grid, particularly in the German and Dutch sectors of the North Sea."
    -   **From article:** "L&T steps in for Petrofac on TenneT’s 2GW offshore wind grid projects"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This project is crucial for accelerating the integration of large-scale renewable energy into the European power grid.
    -   **Supported by:** "In partnership with Hitachi Energy, L&T will deliver HVDC converter stations for the project, which aims to accelerate the integration of large-scale renewable energy into the European power grid, particularly in the German and Dutch sectors of the North Sea."
    -   **From article:** "L&T steps in for Petrofac on TenneT’s 2GW offshore wind grid projects"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Such investments in green energy infrastructure are vital for supporting the broader decarbonization goals that Maersk's low-emission logistics solutions aim to serve.
    -   **Unsupported.** This is an interpretive statement connecting the L&T project to Maersk's goals, not a factual claim supported by the provided sources.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A

-   **Claim:** Discussions at the Maritime CEO Forum in Monaco highlighted widespread uncertainty in the tanker sector, particularly regarding the IMO's stalled net-zero process.
    -   **Supported by:** "If there was one word that dominated discussion at the tanker panel during this year’s Maritime CEO Forum at the Monaco Yacht Club, it was uncertainty — from the IMO’s fractured net-zero process to the unintended consequences of Western sanctions and the rise of the shadow fleet."
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Industry leaders expressed concerns that regulatory proposals often fail to account for the diverse realities of shipping.
    -   **Supported by:** "Svein Moxnes Harfjeld, president and CEO of DHT Holdings, said bluntly that the proposals on the table “didn’t really look at the industry” as it exists today. “We all tend to talk about maritime as a homogeneous industry — and it’s not,” he said. “There are lots of different ships, trades, cargos, short haul, long haul, scheduled and tramp. The proposal didn’t reflect that.”"
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** They also expressed concerns about the practical challenges of scaling alternative fuels like methanol and ammonia, which face issues such as safety, corrosiveness, and competition with other sectors (e.g., ammonia for food production).
    -   **Supported by:** "Moreover, some of the proposed fuels are either extremely dangerous, like ammonia at even a very low concentration in the air or highly corrosive, like methanol."
    -   **From article:** "Shipping calls time on EU climate overreach"
    -   **Confidence:** High

    -   **Supported by:** "She cautioned that shipping will compete with food production for fuels like ammonia. “Eighty percent of ammonia today is used to fertilize crops. The growing population over the next 40 years will need more food than in the past 8,000 years. Shipping will have to compete for these resources.”"
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** There was a strong call for pragmatism over punishment.
    -   **Supported by:** "He argued that the decarbonisation debate has drifted toward punishment over pragmatism."
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This emphasized the need for efficiency improvements within the existing fleet.
    -   **Supported by:** "Alexia Inglessis, director of Alberta Shipmanagement, steered the debate toward practical steps. “With alternative fuels still unavailable, we must focus on efficiency — which also makes business sense,” she said. “Over 40% of the world fleet already has energy-saving devices installed."
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This also emphasized the need for better enforcement of regulations to address issues like the "shadow fleet" of non-compliant vessels.
    -   **Supported by:** "Skov nevertheless insisted that the IMO remains essential. “We need a global voice to regulate the industry. The problem isn’t a lack of regulation — it’s a lack of enforcement.” That theme — enforcement — quickly turned to the proliferation of the shadow fleet. Skov was blunt: “It’s a massive problem that flag states supporting the dark fleet are sitting at the IMO table making decisions about future regulation.”"
    -   **From article:** "Maritime CEO Forum Monaco: Tanker bosses call for realism amid regulatory chaos"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This echoes Maersk's strategic reflections on internal alignment and managing strategic tensions.
    -   **Unsupported.** This is an interpretive statement about Maersk's internal strategies, not a factual claim supported by the provided source material.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A

-   **Claim:** Preparations for the upcoming COP30 climate summit in Belem, Brazil, are facing logistical challenges, with many poorer nations struggling to secure accommodation.
    -   **Supported by:** "Dozens of countries have yet to secure accommodation for their delegations at the COP30 climate summit just a week before it opens... But logistical concerns have plagued preparations: Belem usually has only 18,000 hotel beds, sending nightly rates soaring to several hundred dollars."
    -   **From article:** "Brazil Offers Free Cruise Cabins As Poorer Nations Struggle For Rooms At COP30"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** Brazil is offering free cruise ship cabins to delegations from low-income and climate-vulnerable countries to ensure their participation.
    -   **Supported by:** "A leaked email seen by Reuters showed that Brazil last week offered three free cabins aboard cruise ships moored in Belem to delegations from low-income nations." and "Last week, COP30 president Andre Correa do Lago said the free cabins would go to African countries, small island states and Least Developed Countries — around 96 nations in total, according to Reuters’ calculations."
    -   **From article:** "Brazil Offers Free Cruise Cabins As Poorer Nations Struggle For Rooms At COP30"
    -   **Confidence:** High

-   **Claim:** This situation highlights the ongoing need for equitable access and inclusive representation in global climate policy discussions, a context Maersk follows as it engages with policymakers and the broader sustainability discourse.
    -   **Unsupported.** This is an interpretive statement about Maersk's context, not a factual claim supported by the provided source material.
    -   **Confidence:** N/A
